choices.text: Deny screening as it is done only for woman sexually active for atleast 3 years
Do HPV DNA and screen if she is HPV DNA positive
Subject the woman for pap smear as she is sexually active
Vaccinate her and then start screening

questions.text: 24 year old nulliparous woman ,married for 6 months has come to the OPD for screening against cancer cervix. She has not undergone any screening procedures till date. Your ideal advice to her would be
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec 15th ed

Screening for sexually active woman  should be initiated at the age of 21 years

Screening should be done yearly till the age of 30 and can be shifted to 2 to 3 yearly if 3 consecutive smears are normal.

Screening can be stopped at 70 provided all the smears for the past 10 years are normal.

Hysterectomised women need not be screened further if the hysterectomy was done for a benign condition

HIV positive woman, DES exposure in utero should continue to have annual screening

questions.text: 28 year old multiparous woman with 3 living children who is under regular screening for cancer cervix is diagnosed to have CIN 2 by colposcopic biopsy. The ideal management for this woman would be
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec 15th ed

LEEP is a better option than cryotherapy because more clearance can be obtained with LEEP.

questions.text: In a case of secondary amenorrhea who falls to get withdrawal bleeding after taking E and P, the fault lies at the level of
questions.solution:
Reference : Dutta gynec, 7th ed

If endometrium is intact, bleeding should occur with withdrawal of a combined pill

questions.text: 36 year old multiparous woman comes to the OPD with postcoital bleeding. Examination revealed a mass lesion Of the cervix measuring 2x2 cm and small metastatic lesion in the anterior wall of the upper third of the vagina. Examination of the parametrium and rectal mucosa were not contributory. Punch biopsy of the lesion Revealed squamous cell carcinoma of the ectocervix. Treatment option for this woman should be
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec 15th ed

Trachelectomy is removal of cervix sparing the uterus and is done in nulliparous woman

Both surgery and chemoradiation can be done for this woman

Type 3 radical hysterectomy should be done from 1b1

Treatment option in CaCx

questions.text: Woman diagnosed to have CIN 3 by colposcopic biopsy. Rate of progression to malignancy in her is
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec 15th ed

Risk of malignancy is 1% for CIN 1, 5% for CIN 2 and 20% for CIN 3

questions.text: The most common gynec malignancy associated with HNPCC is
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec 15th ed

LYNCH 11 syndrome

Risk of Ca endometrium is 60%

Ca colon – 54%

Ca ovary – 10%

Surveillance  pelvic exam, TVS, endometrial sampling annually or prophylactic TAH + BSO

choices.text: Hereditary ovarian cancer occur atleast 10 years earlier than sporadic cancers
Borderline ovarian tumors occur at an early age than frankly malignant tumors
Oral contraceptives pills can be used for prophylaxis against hereditary ovarian cancers
Incidence of ovarian cancer is same for BRCA 1 and BRCA 2

questions.text: The following statement is wrong about Carcinoma ovary
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec 15th ed

  • BRCA 1 – chr 17
  • BRCA 2 – chr 13
  • Incidence Of Ca Ovary Is 50% In BRCA 1 & 25% In BRCA 2

OCP Decreases The Risk Of Ovarian And Endomet Cancer In BRCA Positive People But Increases The Risk Of Breast Cancer

  • One child – risk reduction is 3 to 0.4
  • Ocp – risk reduction is5 for ovarian cancer
  • Incidence of hereditary endometrial cancer– 10%
  • Incidence of hereditary ovarian cancer – 5 to 10%
  • Incidence of borderline tumors – 10%
  • Average age of ovarian cancer – 60 years
  • Average age of borderline ovarian cancer – 46 years
  • Hereditary ovarian cancer occur atleast 10 years earlier than sporadic cancers

Kulschitzky Cells are seen in carcinoid tumor

questions.text: 14 year old girl presents with lower abdominal pain and pelvic mass corresponding to 12 weeks gravid uterus. Laparotomy revealed the presence of bilateral ovarian mass with intact capsule and no ascites. Palpation of the Abdominal organs were not contributory. However the capsule was inadvertently ruptured during surgery. Omental biopsy and peritoneal washings were negative for malignancy. She belongs to carcinoma ovary stage
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec, 15th ed

Surgical spill belongs to stage 1c1

questions.text: Chemotherapy for dysgerminoma is:
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec, 15th ed

BEP regimen is the treatment of choice for germ cell tumors of the ovary

Cisplatin and Paclitaxel are the first choice drugs for epithelial ovarian cancers and endometrial cancer

choices.text: Anterior wall is the longest wall

questions.text: False statement about the vaginal mucosa of a 24 year old parous woman are all except
questions.solution:
Reference : Dutta gynec, 6th ed

Posterior vaginal wall is the longest of all

Vagina:

  • No mucous secreting glands
  • No serosal covering
  • Apart from doderlein’s bacilli, it contains many other pathogenic organism including Cl.welchii.

Vaginal Epithelium;

  • Parabasal/basal cells-No hormonal dominance
  • Intermediate cells-Progesterone predominance
  • Supericial cells-Estrogen predominance
  • The intermediate and superficial cells contain glycogen under the influnce of estrogen
  • In newborn females, vagina is lined by transitional epithelium


Almost 25% women harbour candida in the vagina, these are often asymptomatic

choices.text: Patient should come in abstinence for 2 days
Target area is the transformation zone
Slide should be air dried before fixing
Fixative used is ethanol with ether

questions.text: False statement about pap smear
questions.solution:
Reference : Dutta gynec, 6th ed

Immediate fixation should be done and slide should not be air dried

  • Ayres spatula / endocervical brush
  • Precautions
  • 3 slides
  • Fixative - 95% ethanol and ether (equal parts)

methanol for LBC

Bethesda system

ASC

ASCUS & ASC - H

SIL

LSIL & HSIL

AGC

Pap can also diagnose

  • Trichomonas vaginalis
  • Candida
  • Bacterial vaginosis
  • Actinomyces
  • Cellular changes consistent with herpes
  • Cellular changes of iud and radiation

Strawberry vagina and strawberry cervix are features of trichomonas vaginalis

Organisms causing bacterial vaginosis are gardenella vaginalis, mobilincus, peptostreptococci

Partner treatment is not needed for bacterial vaginosis

Paragard is the other name for copper T 380A

questions.text: Morning after pill is

questions.text: 36 year old G3P2L2 has come with 3 months of amenorrhea with giddiness, tachycardia and oliguria. Cervical motion tenderness is positive. Culdocentesis is positive for blood in the POD. Best management option is
questions.solution:
Reference : Dutta obs, 7th ed

Given clinical scenario is typical of ruptured ectopic and the procedure of choice is salpingectomy with tubal ligation in a multiparous woman

questions.text: 32 year old nulliparous woman, married for 8 years has come with irregular periods and pain during menstruation for 2 years. Ultrsound revealed the presence of Complex cyst in the right ovary with Serum CA 125 levels of 95 IU/ml. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec, 15th ed

Ca 125 is very unlikely to be elevated in PCOS

Even though ca 125 is elevated in tuberculosis clinical features of tuberculosis are predominantly infertility,hypomenorrhea or amenorrhea

 

Infertility is more associated with endometriosis

 

Young age, and Ca 125 less than 200 are less likely to be malignancy

choices.text: Most common cause is endometrial atrophy
Office endometrial aspiration is the first step in evaluating suspected endometrial pathology
Pap smear has a false negative rate of upto 50%
Endometrial sampling can be omitted in premenopausal women

questions.text: False regarding postmenopausal bleeding is/are
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec, 15th ed

About 60% of the endometrial pathologies Are due to endometrial atrophy. Remaining 40% are contributed by polyps, malignancy, hyperplasia

Endometrial sampling is mandatory in all cases of abnormal uterine bleeding

Causes of post menopausal bleeding

Endometrial atrophy- 60%

Endometrial hyperplasia- 5 to 15%

Endometrial carcinoma- 10%

Endometrial polyp – 2 to 12%

HRT- 5 to 10%

questions.text: What will be the investigation of choice for a bicornuate uterus?
questions.solution:
Ref: shaws gyn, 16th ed, pg 135

Though ultrasound can diagnose septate and bicornuate uterus, the definitive evidence of septata and bicornuate can be made out only by hysterolaparoscopy

questions.text: Withdrawal bleeding following adminstration of progesterone in a case of secondary amenorrhea indicates all except
questions.solution:
Reference : Dutta gyn, 7th ed

Defect at the level of pituitary or gonad results in total amenorrhea even with progesterone withdrawal

questions.text: Most common site for genital tuberculosis is
questions.solution:
Reference : DC Dutta’s Gynec, 6th Edition, Pg-140

Genital Tuberculosis:

  • Genital tuberculosis is almost always a secondary infection, with M/c primary sites being lungs > lymph nodes > abdomen
  • Route of spread – Hematogenous
  • M/C site is B/L fallopian tubes  (in fallopian tubes – M/c Affected part = Ampulla and M/c encountered pathology is endosalpingitis)
  • M/c age group = 20-30 years (28 years specifically)
  • M/c symptom = Infertility
  • If patient conceives spontaneously, ectopic pregnancy is the most likely outcome.

Hysterosalpingography in TB:

HSG is contraindicated in patients of genital TB as it can lead to reactivation or spreading of disease. But if unknowingly HSG is done in patients of TB.

  • Lead pipe appearance of tube
  • Beaded appearance of tube
  • Hydrosalpinx
  • Cornual block
  • Intravasation of dye
  • Golf club tube
  • Tobacco pouch appearance of the fimbrial end of tube
  • Uterus-Honeycomb appearance due to asherman syndrome.

questions.text: 21 year old mrs x with regular and painful cycles has come with history of recurrent first trimester miscarriages with acne and hirsuitism. Ultrasound of the pelvis revealed 14 follicles of each measuring 3 to 6 mm however her cycles were regular. All of the following can be a part of the management except
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec 15th ed

Even though the diagnosis according to rotterdams criteria is PCOS, regular and painful cycles are more likely to be ovulatory and clomiphene is the least needed drug in this condition

 

Progesterone in the luteal phase is ideal drug for luteal phase defect and should be given for this woman

questions.text: The most common mullerian anomaly is
questions.solution:
Reference : Practical Obstetric problems, Ian donald’s-seventh edition, Pg- 297 

Most common uterine anomaly is septate and the second most common is bicornuate uterus

questions.text: Vaginal rings can be removed for
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws gyn,15th ed, pg 221

Sialistic vaginal rings

50 to 75 mm dm

5 to 9 mm thick

Daily release is 20 micg

Kept in situ for 3 weeks and removed for 1 week

Nuvaring- 120 micg etonorgestrel + 15 mic EE2 daily release

Can be removed for 3 hours a day

Nesterone – 150 mic  progesterone + 15 mic EE2

Failure rate is 1.2/HWY

questions.text: Levonorgestrel is a
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws Gynec, 15th Edition, Pg-311 

Classifications of Progesterone:

  • Pure progesterone- Oral and vaginal micronized progesterone have no adverse effect on lipid profile
  • Pregnane (derived from progesterone molecule), lynes-trenol (allyloestrenol)
  • Estrane (derivative of testosterone)- Norethisterone, norethinyndiol (1st generation)
  • Gonane-Levonorgestrel, norgestrel (2nd generation)
  • 3rd generation progesterone (desogestrel, gestodene, norgestimate). These are less androgenic and cause less metabolic disorders but increase the risk of thrombosis
  • Drospirenone (3 mg equivalent to 25 mg spirinone) now used in oral pills, acne and PCOD. Yasmin contains 30 μg of EE 2 (21 days), Janya contains 20 μg of EE 2 for 24 days in a cycle

Sapparo criteria is for APLA

Mississippi and Tennesse criteria is for HELLP syndrome

Rotterdam’s criteria

PCOS is the most common cause of pathological amenorrhea

Pregnancy is the most common cause of physiological amenorrhea

Failure rates

questions.text: A 25 year old female visits OPD for intertility treatment. During evaluation, hysteroscopy was done and was diagnosed to have Ashermann syndrome. Which of the following symptom the patient is excepted to have
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws textbook of gynec, 15th ed, pg 156,157

Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

Most patients present with hypomenorrhea before amenorrhea sets in. Ashermann’s syndrome is amenorrhea due to intrauterine synechiae formation. M/C cause of ashermann’s syndrome is vigorous uterine curettage in postpartum period but the syndrome can also occur after myomectomy, caesarean section and tuberculosis endometritis.

Management: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis followed by insertion of CuT to prevent reformation of synechiae and cyclical estrogen and progesterone.

questions.text: Biodegradable implant is
questions.solution: Reference : Shaws gyn, 15th ed, pg 221

questions.text: Daily release is least with
questions.solution: Reference : Shaws gyn, 15th ed, pg 221

questions.text: Not a property of third generation progesterone
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws gyn, 15th ed, pg 221

Progesterone only pills are safe during lactation

Cerozette containing 75μg desogestrel has the following advantages over other POPs

  • Stringent time compliance not necessary, as it supresses ovulation in 97%, throuhg pituitary hormone suppression.
  • No androgenic effects like acne.
  • No ectopic pregnancy, no eect on carbohydrate or lipid metabolism
  • Failure rate only 0.21 per 100 women yrars. It acts through metabolic etonogestrel which binds to progesterone receptors

Complications of desogestrel are:

  • Deep venous thrombosis
  • Pulmonary embolism, breast cancer, liver disease, aprt from common complications of progestogens.

choices.text: Ring Pessary is the treatment of choice
Cervical dystocia may occur during labor
Not an Absolute indication for LSCS

questions.text: 26year old G2P1L1 with 12 weeks pregnancy presents with 3rd degree UV prolapse. True about the following condition are
questions.solution:
Reference : Ian Donald's practical obstetric problems, 7th edition, pg-301

 

The maximum size of the uterus that can descend through the vagina is 12 weeks. Beyond 12 weeks uterus becomes an abdominal organ and is well supported by pelvic brim. Hence in the second trimester it spontaneously resolves.

 

If the condition is unattended and the cervix is lying constantly outside the introitus, it can become edematous,ulcerated and irreducible

 

Cervical dystocia may occur during labor and there is risk of rupture of lower segment although cervical dilation and spontaneous vaginal delivery occurs in most cases since they occur in multiparous women. Hence it is not an absolute indication for cesarean section.

 

  1. The incidence of prolapse during pregnancy is very rare. It usually occurs in multiparous women. Most cases are pregnancies in pre existing prolapse.

 As far as the options are concerned always remember that the maximum size of the uterus that can descend through the vagina is 12 weeks. Beyond 12 weeks uterus becomes an abdominal organ and is well supported by pelvic brim. Hence in the second trimester it spontaneously resolves.

For prolapses which does not resolve spontaneously ring Pessary should be adequate.

In cases where prolapse develops during pregnancy it appears during late second or third trimester.

If the condition is unattended and the cervix is lying constantly outside the introitus, it can become edematous,ulcerated and irreducible. Other complications during pregnancy include UTI, preterm labor, PPROM, sepsis and urinary retention. Cervical dystocia may occur during labor and there is risk of rupture of lower segment although cervical dilation and spontaneous vaginal delivery occurs in most cases since they occur in multiparous women. Hence it is not an absolute indication for cesarean section.

choices.text: Point A is 2cm above and lateral to external OS
Point B is 4cm lateral to point A
Point B corresponds to obturator nodes

questions.text: All are true about radiotherapy for Ca Cx except
questions.solution:
Reference : Novak's gynaecology 15th edition,pg-1325

  • Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for Ca Cx Stage 1b2 and above.
  • Primary radiation treatment plan consists of a combination of external teletherapy to treat the regional lymph nodes and to decrease the tumour volume and brachytherapy delivered by intracavitary applicators or interstitial implants to treat the central tumour.
  • The usual doses delivered are 7000 to 8000 cGy to point A defined as 2 cm superior to external os and 2 cm lateral to internal uterine canal and 6000 cGy to point B Defined as 3 cm lateral to point A.
  • Point A corresponds to the point of crossing of uterine Artery with the ureter.
  • Point B corresponds to obturator nodes.

questions.text: According to figo classification of fibroids, a Submucus fibroid which is less than 50% inside the myometrium belongs to fibroid no
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec, 15th ed

SM-Submucosal:

0 - Pedunculated intracavitary

1 - <50% Intramural

2 - ≥ 50% intramural

 

O-Other:

3- Contact endometrium, 100% intramural

4- Intramural

5- Suberosal ≥ 50% intramural

6- Suberosal <50% intramural

7- Subserosal pedunculated

8- Other (epecify e.g. cervical, parasitic)

 

Hybrid Leiomyomas:

Two numbers are listed separated by a hyphen, By convention the first refers to the relationship with the endometrium while the second refers to the relationship to the serosa.

questions.text: Polycythemia is a complication of
questions.solution:
Reference : Sheila balakrishnan gynec, pg 167

Most commons in Fibroid:

  • Fibroids are most commonly Uterine
  • MC uterine fibroid is interstitial
  • All fibroids to begin with start as an interstitial fibroid
  • MC extra uterine fibroid is cervical fibroid
  • A pedunculated subserous fibroid sometimes detached itself from the uterus and gets attached to a vascular organ and exists independently – Parasitic fibroid
  • Most symptomatic fibroid is submucous fibroid
  • MC fibroid causing retention of urine – Anterior and Central cervical fibroids
  • MC fibroid to undergo necrosis - submucous fibroid
  • MC fibroid to undergo calcareous degeneration - subserous
  • MC fibroid to undergo malignant change – submucous
  • Lantern on St.Paul’s church refers to a cervical fibroid

MC fibroid to undergo torsion – Pedunculated subserous fibroid

questions.text: Emily is
questions.solution:
Reference :

Emily is a sterile, levonogestrel releasing intrauterine system indicated for:

  • Intrauterine contraception for up to 3years, in women who have at least one child.
  • Treatment of heavy menstrual bleeding for women who suffer from dysfunctional uterine bleeding and who are willing to accept LNG IUD as an alternative to hysterectomy or oral medications.

Dosage & Administration

  • Release rate of levonogestrel is approximately 20 mcg per day; Emily should be replaced after 3 years.
  • To be inserted by a trained healthcare provider using strict aseptic technique. Healthcare providers are advised to become thoroughly familiar with the insertion instructions before attempting insertion
  • Patient should be re-examined and evaluated 4 to 12 weeks after insertion; then, yearly or more often if indicated

questions.solution:
Reference : Practical Obstetric problems, Ian donald’s-seventh edition, Pg- 297

. Classification of mullerian duct anomalies

  1. Hypoplasia/ Agenesis
    1. Vaginal
    2. Cervical
    3. Fundal

    5. Combined
  2. Unicornuate
    1. Communicating
    2. Non- Communicating
  3. Didelphys
  4. Bicornuate
    1. Complete
    2. Partial
  5. Septate
    1. Complete
    2. Partial
  6. Arcuate
  7. DES related

Long term sequel

choices.text: MTP is approved for contraceptive failure
GA should be not more than 12 weeks
Methotrexate can be used for 1st trimester MTP

questions.text: False regarding MTP act
questions.solution:
Reference : Ref: Textbook of Gynaecology, Sheila Balakrishnan, Pg-374.

  • MTP act Liberalisation of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act was approved by Parliament in the year 1971 and was implemented in 1972 and revised in 1975. It was last amended in 2006. It lays down the conditions under which MTP can be performed in India (indications, persons who can perform the procedure and the place). By law, MTP in India is permitted up to 20 weeks of gestation.

choices.text: Uterine sign is always higher for GA

questions.text: All of the following are true about a complete mole except
questions.solution:
Reference : Novaks gynec, 15th ed

Uterine size is high for GA in 25%, low for GA in 25% and normal for GA in 50%

  • Features of complete and partial hydatidiform moles

choices.text: Recurrence in groin is universally fatal
Contralateral groin dissection can be omitted for more lateral lesions
Separate incision for groin dissection and tumor excision improve wound healing
Role of deep inguinal node as a sentinel node is being investigated.

questions.text: False statement about vulval cancer is /are
questions.solution:
Reference : Novks gynec, 15th ed

Lesions more than 2 cm from the midline does not need contralateral nodal dissection

Sentinel node for vulval cancer is superficial inguinal lymphnode

High yielding Facts about vulvar cancer

  • Vulvar lesions require biopsy to avoid delay in diagnosis
  • The modern approach to patients with vulvar cancer is multidisciplinary and individualized
  • Management of the primary lesion and groin nodes is determined separately
  • Most t1,t2 and early t3 lesionsssss can be managed with radical local excision
  • Large t3 and t4 primary tumors are best treated with chemoradiation followed by more limited surgical resection
  • When groin dissection is indicated it should be a thorough inguinofemoral lymphe
  • The potential role of sentinel lymph node procedure to eliminate the need of a complete inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is being investigated
  • The single most important prognostic factor is lymph node status
  • Postoperative radiation decreases the risk of groin recurrence in patients with multiple positive inguino femoral lymph nodes
  • Recurrence in the groin is almost universally fatal

questions.text: A 39 year old female para 2, complains of severe progressive secondary dysmennorhea. Pelvic examination revealed a tender diffuse enlarged uterus with no adnexal tenderness. Endometrium biopsy came normal. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws textbook of gynec, 15th ed, pg 474,475

Endometriosis is likely to have adnexal tenderness with normal or bulky uterus

Other features of infection like foul smelling discharge and fever suggest endometritis

Uterus may be regularly or irregularly enlarged with fibroids but the condition is usually non tender

Adenomyosis:

Adenomyosis is a condition where there is ingrowth of endometrium (both gland + stroma) directly into the myometrium. Earlier it was called as endometriosis interna.

Age Group: Elderly patients > 40 years

Parity: Multiparous

Symptoms:

Most common symptom: Menorrhagia

2nd most common symptom: Dysmenorrhea

Others: Pelvic discomfort, backache, dyspareunia

On per vaginal examination:

Symmetrical enlargement of uterus (not more than 12-14 weeks of pregnancy), mobility not restricted, no associated adnexal pathology.

Halbans sign- Tender, softened uterus on premenstrual bimanual examination.

Diagnosis: 

  • Mainly Clinical
  • Transvaginal ultrasonography or MRI (Junctional zone thickness > 12 mm) are helpful

Management:

  • Surgery
  • Levonorgestrel containing IUCDs

questions.text: All of the following are 2nd generation ablative techniques except
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws gyn, 15th ed

First generation: TCRE

Roller ball coagulation

Second generation:

radio frequency induced thermal ablation caveteRm balloon therapy microwave

choices.text: Pre operative endometrial thinning is not required

questions.text: Advantages of 2nd generation ablative techniques over 1st generation techniques are
questions.solution: Reference : Shaws gyn, 15th ed

questions.text: Halbans disease is otherwise called as
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws gyn, 15th ed, Dutta gyn 6th ed.

  • Endometrial pattern in irregular shedding : Endometrial sapling performed after 5th or 6th day of the onset of menstruation reveals a mixture of secretory and proliferative endometrium. There is total absence of any surface epithelium
  • Endometrial pattern in irregular ripening: Endometrial study prior to or soon after spotting reveals patchy area of secretory changes amidst proliferative endometrium

questions.text: The instrument is commonly used for
questions.solution:
Reference : Dutta obs, 7th ed

The given instrument is pipelle’s endometrial curettage, used for endometrial sampling in suspected endometrial pathologies.

It is an blind OPD procedure

Anesthesia is not required.

questions.text: Degree of inversion if fundus of the uterus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina is
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws textbook of gynec, 15th ed, pg349

Fundal dimple-1st degree

Fundus lies in the vagina- 2nd degree

Fundus protrudes through the introitus- 3rd degree

choices.text: Review after 2-3 months for ovarian cyst

questions.text: A 26 year old female presents in OPD for dull aching lower abdomen pain. She had previous two normal vaginal deliveries. Her LMP was 3 weeks ago. On P/V examination a cystic mass was felt in the left fornix region, which on USG was found to be a left clear ovarian cyst of 5 cm. which of the following is recommended for this patient
questions.solution:
Reference : Shaws gynec, 15th edition, pg 369

Corpus luteum (granulose lutein) cysts are functional, non-neoplastic enlargements of the ovary. Persistent cor-pus luteum cyst may cause local pain, tenderness or delayed menstruation. These cysts are often palpable clinically. Unless complication like torsion or rupture lead to an acute abdomen requiring surgical treatment, most cysts will resolve in due course of time. Hence observation is recommended whenever this condition is suspected.

Functional cysts are recognized from neoplastic cyst by the fact that they never grow more than 7cm in size, are unilocular with clear fluid and regress after some time.
